channel.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
channel.description:
Megaupload was shut down and the owner's were sued today. The reason it was taken down for was copyright infringement, which is stupid since you can't help that if you're Megaupload. They should have just sued the uploader, but w/e.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i2dro8iIto0

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

ytuio9`:

Wait so basically, if I file a takedown notice for a legal video, is youtube obliged to take it down?

you can do that if you really want to but a dmca is filed under penalty of perjury, if you don’t own the copyright(or even if you do) the person who had the video can issue a counter notice and if it isn’t resolved then and there they can take you to the courts to decide

Spades:

But if you are reporting someone else for uploading content that doesn’t belong to you or them, they will bypass it.

youtube cannot decides who owns what copyright, they must take the video down (provided the dmca is filed correctly etc etc) and let the video owner decide if it wants to stay down or let them file a counter notice and possibly take it to the courts

of course there’s nothing stopping you going around filing false dmcas other than the very real threat of getting fucked over in a court for it

Read full topic

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

ytuio9`:

Wait so basically, if I file a takedown notice for a legal video, is youtube obliged to take it down?

I highly doubt they’re just going to go on a blind rage of take-down notices, and even then, you saw how Jagex filed a DMCA takedown towards Moparisthebest, he hasn’t taken anything down and we are still operating!

Read full topic

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

ytuio9`:

Wait so basically, if I file a takedown notice for a legal video, is youtube obliged to take it down?

Usually they ignore us because we aren’t the ones who own the copyright material. But if you make a video with you and your friends and post it to youtube, and another person re-uploads it, then you can claim it as yours and they can take it down. But if you are reporting someone else for uploading content that doesn’t belong to you or them, they will bypass it.

Read full topic

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Andrew Ferguson:

Niall, I was stating that it’s funny that Mediafire is still around, I’m not saying they are immune, I’m just saying that it’s basically the best known way to get free music other then torrents and it still exists. We aren’t misinformed, we are pointing out funny flaws. Mediafire has been a known site for uploaded illegal content since it first opened because it provided scans of the items uploaded so you could download stuff you would get from a torrent virus free.

it isn’t funny or strange provided they comply with all dmca takedown notices and have a legal requirement to do so

illegal songs and videos get uploaded to youtube all the time and as long as the copyright holder or someone on behalf of the copyright holder doesn’t file a takedown notice there’s no legal requirement to take it down, the only thing that matters is the takedown notice is upheld and that youtube leaves the decisions of who owns the copyright to the courts and not take it into their own hands

Read full topic

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Pblord7:

The reason it was taken down for was copyright infringement, which is stupid since you can’t help that if you’re Megaupload.

well actually, you can help it, and are legally required to “help it”

you see, should you own the copyright to a song and a website is hosting it illegally, you can file a dmca takedown notice to that website to have the content removed

that website has 2 options, take the content down and keep their safe harbour status, or they can keep the content up and take full liability for the illegally hosted material

in a nutshell megaupload chose the second option and didn’t remove the illegally hosted material

[quote=“New fag, post:5, topic:429872”]There is nothing illegal for getting legal money through legal means for providing a legal service.
If we follow that principle on which MU is taken down is Google next then?[/quote]

the illegal part comes from megaupload ignoring the dmca takedown notices therefore giving up their safe harbour status

if youtube kept a video up after receiving a dmca takedown then the same thing could happen to youtube, it’s not a case of big bad government and copyright holders going after an innocent website

B2300 T4nk:

SOPA is the reason why this happened.

no it isn’t

[quote=“killadragz14, post:7, topic:429872”]A funny thing is they sue them for a copy right fragments when they have over 1 billion users?
Im pretty sure megauplaod has a privacy policy stating that they can’t monitor every download.[/quote]

they DON’T need to monitor every upload, the part where a hosted song becomes illegal is when the copyright holder sends a notice to the website stating they believe the material to be illegally hosted and requiring the website to take it down, should the website not take it down the website waives any safe harbour rights and take FULL RESPONSIBILITY for ALL HOSTED MATERIAL

xryz:

I hope megaupload wins the case. it is so bs.

it’s so bullshit that megauploaded chose to ignore their legal rights and took full responsibility for any hosted content?

xryz:

charging them for crimes their users have committed, not what megaupload has been doing. like megaupload im sure those services were created for useful purposes but have been abused by their users.

well you see, while the users may have been uploading copyrighted content, megaupload made money off of this and decided to ignore the dmca takedown notices they received and continued to host this illegal content, as a content provider you are 100% liable for the hosted content and should you decide to give up your safe harbour status you can be taken to court for it

xryz:

and they have ways to report copyright material which if said material is copyright I’m sure they remove it from their servers.

yes there are ways to remove copyrighted content from a website, megauploaded ignored this and CONTINUED TO HOST THE ILLEGAL CONTENT THEREBY GIVING UP THEIR SAFE HARBOUR STATUS AND TAKING ALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE HOSTED MATERIAL WHICH IS WHAT THIS COURT CASE IS ALL ABOUT

[quote=“Mitko, post:47, topic:429872”][quote]because megaupload uploaded the piracy themselves, and knowingly promoted it, while rewarding users for uploading DVD rips
also they don’t delete files when they get a DMCA[/quote]
Not sure if it’s true.[/quote]

if it isn’t true then they will win the court case

but they’re not going to win because it is true, megaupload didn’t remove the copyright infringing files

Andrew Ferguson:

The funny thing is, one of the reasons it was shut down is because so much illegal music got uploaded to it and they didn’t remove it, but you can google anything and type mediafire at the end and you will get 10+ links (music wise).

and if mediafire chooses to ignore the dmca takedown notice and doesn’t remove the copyrighted material they too will lose their safe harbour status and could have the exact same thing happen

and if youtube chooses to ignore the dmca takedown notice and doesn’t remove the copyrighted material they too will lose their safe harbour status and could have the exact same thing happen

and if any us hosted website, or any hosting website in a country with treaties with the us chooses to ignore the dmca takedown notice and doesn’t remove the copyrighted material they too will lose their safe harbour status and could have the exact same thing happen

sure is misinformed in here

Read full topic

item.title: Megaupload Shutdown?
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:54, topic:429872”][quote author=xryz link=topic=532555.msg3893433#msg3893433 date=1327103396]
I hope megaupload wins the case. it is so bs. if the US wins then I’m suing the government for making services that US and non-US citizens abusing government services like the IRS, SSI, and welfare programs; for tax evasion, welfare fraud, because that’s basically what they are doing to megaupload; charging them for crimes their users have committed, not what megaupload has been doing. like megaupload im sure those services were created for useful purposes but have been abused by their users.

I was watching BBC news this morning, first time every watching it, b/c it had news about megaupload and they made it seem like megaupload’s whole purpose was for illegal activity. racketeering… so every file-sharing service is an illegal business is basically what they are saying; money laundering is cancelled out since megaupload isnt an illegal means of income; everything they offer site-wise not file-sharing server-wise is all their own and know other’s work but megaupload’s work, and they have ways to report copyright material which if said material is copyright I’m sure they remove it from their servers.
[/quote]

FYI: that was megaupload’s whole purpose. It wasn’t that megaupload contained illegal material from their users, it’s that the owners uploaded copyright material themselves, and went on bragging about it. They were morons.[/quote]
^ This.
They were basically an illegal version of netflix on their site “Megavideo”, charging like $8 a month for any movie ever.

Read full topic

I was watching BBC news this morning, first time every watching it, b/c it had news about megaupload and they made it seem like megaupload’s whole purpose was for illegal activity. racketeering… so every file-sharing service is an illegal business is basically what they are saying; money laundering is cancelled out since megaupload isnt an illegal means of income; everything they offer site-wise not file-sharing server-wise is all their own and know other’s work but megaupload’s work, and they have ways to report copyright material which if said material is copyright I’m sure they remove it from their servers.[/quote]

The civil war was over something else, that was due mostly to slavery.
The worst that could happen is possible have the government fired?
or states could go back to being independent and break from US which would cripple, them then they would have to change it.
[/quote]
Well thing is that if US places a law since, we are one of the free nations alot of people wan tto be like us, so they will put laws like ours into their own country.

If that does happen then there would be no worries about anything… Im from the UK and i know that the shitty UK government won’t do anything like this…[/quote]
Well most countries follow what we do, cause they want to be like us.
So i wouldn’t be surprised if this law passed that other countries wouldn’t follow.

Speljohan:

That anyone actually thinks this is the work of SOPA (which isn’t even implemented) is staggering. GET FUCKING EDUCATED ALREADY

My friend there is where you are wrong.
The reason sopa is trying to take place is due to the entertainment business.
That is why the US sued them for Copyrighted material cause they had films, that was copyrighted in the US, so the US decided well hey we are going to be greedy and start taking money.
Most of this is due to the sopa bill that is trying to be passed.
Seeing how Megaupload was made in 2006, and the US decided now to sue them?
Sorry to say but im sure US has known about Megaupload for years.
Education has nothing to do with this either.
